section.title: Introduction
section.para: The onCourse Editor is your platform to create, manage and distribute information to your website. The Editor is a Content Managment System (CMS) that provides simple but powerful tools to manage the struture and content of your website in a collaborative environment.

section.title: Setting up Access to the Editor
section.para: Before you start editing content within the Editor you need to set up a user name and password to log in.

onCourse enables any user to also have the ability to log into and edit content within the CMS using the same log in credentials for the Editor that you use to access the onCourse Client . To do this go to File > Preferences > Users and open the relevant record, then tick the box 'Can edit CMS'.

caption.para: Enabling Editor Access within onCourse User Profile

section.title: Logging In
section.para: You can access the editor by visiting your name site and adding '#editor' at the end of the url. For example, if your website url is 'http://www.acme.com.au' the editor can be accessed at 'xml http://www.acme.com.au#editor'.

section.title: The Editor View

caption.para: Finding your way around the Editor view

section.para: Once logged in, a new toolbar will be visible o the left hand side of the browser window. You can continue to browse through your site as normal while logged into the Editor.

Across the left of the screen you will find icons that allows you to quickly access the primary areas of the Editor. In addition, you will also see an option to publish any changes you've made to the live site, as well as view a log of all recent changes to the site.

section.title: Editing Content
section.para: Clicking the Content Icon will take you to the editor for Blocks, Pages and Themes. These three components make up the strucutre of the website.

section.title: Blocks
section.para: Blocks are the cornerstone to your website's variety and page dynamics. For example if you wanted an element (a banner for example) on every page of your web site, then blocks are your answer. If you wanted an area on several different pages dedicated to a contact form, blocks are ideal. Blocks are re-usable snippets of text, pictures, rich text markup, javascript, etc.

caption.para: The Blocks page allows you to easily add, search and edit blocks.

section.para: Selecting a block will take you to the Editor page for that specific block. Here, you can change the name of the block, as well as editing it's content. On the righ side of the screen you will see a rendering of what the block will look like on your website

Clicking on the block contents will open the block in a text editor view. Here, you can write markup text or html to be added to the block. Clicking save will close the text editor and render your changes for you to view.

section.title: Pages
section.para:
Many pages generated in your "onCourse" website will be content automatically generated from your Course, Classes, and Tutor descriptions. Some of the pages in your site have URLs like this:
/courses
/courses/arts/photography
/course/ABC
/sites
/tutor/123
/site/234
/checkout

Additionally, you can create 'static' pages to your website. These allows you to add additional content to add breadth and cohesion to your website. For example, you may like to add an "about us" or "contact" page.

The Pages view will list of all the static pages in your site and gives you quick access to search for, edit and delete pages. Similar to the Block view, clicking on a Page will open that Page in a text editor view.

Here, you can change the theme that is applied to this page, the pages name, as well as editting the content of the page. You can also elect whether any given page is 'avaiable'. Pages that are not marked as available can only be accessed with their direct url link. Keep pages that you don't want users stumbling across, or that may be under contruction as 'invisible'.
